title: Sign up for the High School AU & NZ Championship

replies.body: So when im in highschool you hype uni championships now at uni and you put highschool championships?!? >:(

It is pretty funny they've abandoned uni esports after only 2 years. I am president of University of Adelaide's League club and since Woody Wu (Marauder) left Riot Oce we've been completely forgotten.

Hey guys, we haven't forgotten about University esports don't worry! 

I was at the Unisport launch the other day and I think their restructure is going to be good for the tournament we run with them. 

Plus we've got some exciting news coming up regarding the OCS and a University as well (sorry for the sizzle, stay tuned)

My university told me League of Legends would no longer be part of the new Unisports event. Should probably reach out to universities so they can prepare. Mine has all their teams for other sports ready to go now.
Hi Lalna, that's definitely not the case as we're actively working with them. Thanks for letting us know though, we'll reach out to clear up the communication.

Note: This is coming from someone who's currently advising in the Taekwondo (UTS) department so my information may not necessarily apply to the eSports field. But best talk to your sports faculty and the hardcore gaming society to see what's the go.

I believe with the recent changes at Australian University Sport and the Australian University Games, esports is now being reconsidered for a major overhaul as a competition item at the National University Games this September.
League's main issue i think is that they currently have no delegate administrator who's contacting the AUS department so my best suggestion is if someone from say Griffith university (it's being held in the Gold Coast this year) can reach out to them and facilitate it that would be League's best shot at coming back to the Uni Championship Scene
is there any rank limitation for us to register the tournaments?

There's no limit on rank - just a desire to do your best!  Other than that, all you need to do is get a team of 5 together and a teacher who will support you during the season.  Once you have that you can get your teacher to register your team in at the correct site for your state above.

Good luck!
Is it a knockout competition or like a ladder?

More like a ladder - each region will likely be a touch different, depending on the number of schools, but the main part of the tournaments will be structured around regular/weekly play.  There will be playoffs and finals toward the end which might be knockout though :)

Regular games in the tournament will be held online - meaning you can play together with your team from school or anywhere that is suitable for you.   The dates depend a little on which state you are in, but will likely be in the back half of Term 2 and also Term 3.
Thank you very much, and one more thing where will the games be held and when like the date and time?
Will there be more information to our teacher's or our support person or to us?
thank you!
You cannot be in the OCE Pro league
Spelling mistake in the last line. "Will ~~you~~ your** high school rule the Rift?". :D
Fixed – thanks for the catch!
No problems

whoa

after the TM drama and the subsequent cluster mess u called an investigation,people and sponsors left in droves,we were severely let dowm by oce riot boss,and his bs favouritism towards the owner.no one wants to see that ever again
Damn, everyone who played League in Caboolture State High School just finished year 12.
Huh, I was planning on going to CSHS. Small world, I guess. If you still go there and are looking for players, I know some people who might be interested in playing in the champs.

no sorry 
I completed year 12 along with, from what I know, every other league player

How many teams are allowed from each school? I know for sure that there are more than 5 people that attend my school that are better than me, but I am considering just entering for shits and giggles. We do, of course, want to win, but are not expecting too much from our silver skillz.

Playing in a comp like this can be a great way to level up your skills with your friends.  Final numbers might depend a bit from state to state, so get your teacher to sign up with as many as you've got, and the tournament organiser will be able to help you from there.

Just a thought but would it be better for high school leagues to start early in term 1 and finish end of term 2?? For seniors they have exam prep around halfway thru term 3 and into the 4th term. This could either disrupt their studies or make some of the student to be dissuaded into competing.

Thanks for the feedback Kuhaku.  

We're certainly aware of exams, which is absolutely why we're trying to stay clear of the last term as much as possible.   By the time the second half of Term 3 rolls around, we expect most competitors will have finished, with each state final happening around then, and only state finalists continuing in the AU+NZ finals.

Importantly, by having a teacher involved in each team, we'd expect that they work with competitors to make sure they balance training with study accordingly.  It is actually a requirement of the competition that your academic performance does not drop.
How many teams are allowed per school?

This may depend a little from state to state.  I'd suggest letting the tournament organisers know how many teams you have and work with them to include them in the comp.   More teams = more challenges!
Im 2 trash to play probs (what is the prize??)
I go to a college, which strictly speaking isn't a high school. Still eligible?

Wehn you say college do you mean a Unversity college?  Or a college teaching high school subjects (eg. "Mindstar Secondary College")?  If it's the second one, then you should be able to make a team and get involved!
